channel.name: Representing Decimal Numbers In A Field

messages.content:
Good afternoon,

I am seeking for the best way to represent Decimal values using `Field`. My specific goal is of representing latitude and longitude, which are in the form of decimal values.

The documentation does not appear to dive deep into this topic, the answers that I searched here contain broken links, I couldn't find any relevant code samples in a reasonable amount of time, as such I'm asking the question here.

My current approach lies in scaling, but it would be of great value if you could provide me with information regarding the usual ways of achieving my goal. I am currently looking into quantizaiton, but perhaps there is something pre-built for that puropse.

Thank you.
do you need to do any floating point math? for starters you could split the number into two UINT64, where one would store the decimals
normally in blockchain math, we work with whole numbers, so if your coords have like 8 decimals, and the main number has 2 digits, then you need a total of 10 digits to represent it as a whole number
pardon my math terminology i’m not PHD native
Another solution is to have 2 Fields and to calculate the float as Field1/Field2
or pick a multiplier high enough to represent all decimals as a whole number + excess, so that you dont loose too much precision on eg division
1.005 * 10^18 = 1 005 000 000 000 000 000 in your Field/Uint64 (if it even fits)
Or, in case with latitude and longitude, you know min and max values, so it can be min + Field/MaxField * (max-min)
btw field division isnt the same as uint64 division
its some special field division, not the one you’d expect
@maht0rz best source on the field specifics would be the Mina book, right?

You can have the SmartContract that uses Fields and the TypeScript class Coords that has functions toFields and fromFields to have the standard interface for conversion. 
One more way is to create a MerkleMap or MerkleTree and put there everything coords related you want to store)))

Hello illya, great question! From my perspective, I think one of the most efficient ways is to store all the information you need in 1 single Field, so that it is more optimized in terms of memory and complexity. For instance, if you will store floating point number in the interval [-1e8, 1e8] with the 8 first floating digits (I mean 8 following digits after the decimal point), then you need 17 bytes to represent these numbers. Fields can take already up to 70 bytes 🙂 I already have an implementation of this as a maths library (it is a bit outdated I am afraid, but the basic functions should be still working if you update it to o1js from snarkyjs). I am sending the link https://github.com/yunus433/snarkyjs-math, please let me know if you have any questions. In this implementation, library supports for decimals with 8 Field precision in the range [-1e18, 1e18]. Unfortunately it uses 2 Fields to represent them right now (but this can be changed easily, the second one is only for number's sign and easily be included in the main value of number). Basic arithmetic functions are working pretty well, but I am afraid there are some precision issues with trigonometric and logarithmic functions

@Yunus Gürlek thanks a lot for your answer. I am actually developing a solution which is in the same direction that you described. I'm converting all of the math to consider the fact that the decimal values are encoded into integers with a specific precision. I also appretiate the code and will study it. I will write back if I require some additional help!

No worries, small note on encoding decimals to integers: you should not make equality assertions to implement division or multiplication, but instead you should check for precision (isInPrecisionRound method does this in the current implementation). Also, note that the rounding of JS does not work as precise as it should after some decimals. That’s why I have implemented a seperate big integer library working on standard JS numbers as strings. It is basically a big float library. That can also be useful 🙂 Finally, if you update the maths library and fix the compatibility issues pls make a PR, so that everyone can continue using it 😃 Thank you!

Thanks for the extra information @Yunus Gürlek. I do have two follow-up questions:

> you should not make equality assertions to implement division or multiplication, but instead you should check for precision (isInPrecisionRound method does this in the current implementation).
Can you please provide a concrete example?

> Also, note that the rounding of JS does not work as precise as it should after 4-5 decimals. That’s why I have implemented a seperate big integer library working on standard JS numbers as strings.
Does this also apply to integers? Or are you talking about using decimals directly in JavaScript (meaning not `Field`s).

Yes of course, about the precision check example: Think you divide 1 by 3. Then the result is 0.333333.... This should be rounded to 0.33333333 (If you keep 8 digits of precision in your Field).  If you remultiply this number by 3, then it will become 0.99999999, and it won't be rounded (as it has only 8 digits, not 9). So if you try to say 1 ?= 0.99999999 then this equality would fail, which is something we do not want. To solve this, a possible approach is to never have equality checks, but always to check if a number is "in precision range" of another. So for 8 digits of rounding, you would look if the absolute difference between two floating point numbers is smaller than 1e-8, allowing you to compare them in a way that makes more sense in most of applications. (see inPrecisionRange implementations in CircuitNumber and CircuitNumberExact models in the library above)

About JS divisions, this comes from the fact that most of the time we do not write the complex operations from scratch, but instead use the inverse operation to assert the result. Think about division and multiplication. Having native multiplication on numbers that are represented as strings is not really hard, you just multiply each digit and do necessary roundings etc. But implementing division on strings is actually really hard. So instead of doing so, we use JS division inside a Provable.witness call. (Again see CircuitNumber.div)
Then, we assert that the CircuitNumber we have calculated with native JS division is indeed the ZK result by applying a provable multiplication  on it

Actually, as far as I know this is how complex operations like square root etc are implemented on the field type. They just calculate the native sqrt, and then assert in the end that it equals the input when it is multiplied by itself.

However, there is a problem with this approach when we work with numbers with more than 8-9 floating points. JS division is not that precise. (It is not logarithmic, it actually approximates results in almost constant time). So when you make a division that rounds after a considerable amount of digits, then the results becomes not precise enough. For instance, let's say you divide 315 by 314 (prime among them). The result is 1.00318471337579617.... (You must use a full precision calculator to see the actual result, these calculators have logarithmic division and work on strings). But JS says it equals 1 .0031847133757963, so the last digit is not in precision range (it is 2 * 1e17). So the assertion fails. However, this case becomes important with really high precision, as the case in CircuitNumberExact class. I have implemented this class to work with very complex mathemetical operations like sin, cos, etc., and it still has some problems. So maybe this comment would not be valid for your case, but just wanted to warn you that you cannot trust native JS functions if you work with very precise floating point numbers. Thus you need a BigNumber library that will treat floating point numbers as strings and perform logarithmic division

Btw, one more time for more clarification: I was talking about native JS / TS operations, not Field type methods. They are really precise actually, that's a reason why we do not like equality checks but do precision checks when we try implementing floating point numbers with fix rounding 🙂
